"Friendly company culture, bad mentorship plan for on job training"

Former Employee
pros: HKA is a young airline comparing to the other HKG based airlines. The culture in the company is friendly and not much distance between senior and junior staffs. Greater opportunities are provided to workers to develop their interests in the industry.
cons: Some staffs refuse to be the mentor of new joiners as they think they will be an obstacle for them to work. The situation keeps going and eventually, the new joiners are not well trained as their mentorship didn't go well. And then, the management will think that the poor performances of the new joiners after mentorship are due to the new joiner himself or herself. They don't review the quality of the mentors who supposed to train and monitor the new joiner and set up standard training guidelines for training new joiner but blame the new joiners for their poor performance which is because of the poor training provided.
advice_to_mgmt: Always review the training guidelines and improving the mentorship plan can help you to keep the staffs and stop them from resigning as they can build up the confidence in performing the tasks from a better training plan. Sometimes, it's not the trainees' performance problems but the trainers' quality problems to bring out the issues.

headline: Horrible company, poor management in HKG, no respect for staff.
status:
9 September 2018
Helpful (3)
"Horrible company, poor management in HKG, no respect for staff."
1.0
★★★★★
Former Employee
pros:
- Some of the passengers are nice, and make you smile.
- Discounted staff travel (but not as good compared to other companies).
- No two days are the same.
cons:
- Extremely poor management. The management couldn't care less about you as an employee, you're simply a number to them not a person.
-Management style is very 'mainland chinese'. They continue 'threatening' you. i.e 'If you don't do this you will be punished'.
- Very low pay compared to other airlines. 'Bonuses' are a joke, and you could only buy a cup of coffee with it.
- No company inter-departmental co-operation. Different departments don't work together so finding an answer to a question is difficult.
- HR Department is a joke. The time I was there they went through FOUR HR senior managers, so finding an answer to your question is extremely challenging.
- No redundancy payment.
- You have to put up with a LOT of challenges in the workplace. It's not an easy job, and you always go home worrying or HAVE to work for home (because if you don't HQ will call you and tell you off). The pay doesn't reflect all the things you need to go through.
- 'Staff workplace feedback surveys' are a JOKE. Why ask for feedback on how the company is performing if you're not going to act on it? And why ask us to put our name on it? Surely if you wanted our honest feedback you'd make it anonymous.
advice_to_mgmt: Instead of sitting in your office, come down to the airport one day and experience what we have to go through. Don't keep threatening us with disciplinary action, and let us have our days off. When you ask for our feedback on the workplace, actually act on it. No wonder why so many staff are resigning. We stay because we simply need to get paid. We don't stay because we love it.
